"In Singapore, only known from old collections from the Botanic Gardens, Tanglin and a cemetary. It may not be native."		"Published as Rediscovered in error. The specimen found and reported by Lee et al. (2005) was ""found"" in SBG in the fernery and is filed in the Cultivated herbarium at SING. Ridley did not report this species in his accounts of the ferns of Malaya. Holttum said he had seen it in Singapore at a few places around town. 13					no	Excluded	no	no				Antrophyum parvulum Blume	574	ok	Name and authors accepted by LCVP	IPNI (= POWO)	x	1			n/a		https://www.ipni.org/n/17023450-1					Antrophyum parvulum	Monilophyta	Polypodiopsida	Polypodiales	Pteridaceae	no	"No evidence for this in Singapore. I suspect Johnson (1977, p114) and Turner (1993) misapplied this name to Antrophyum callifolium (despite these 2 species having different paraphyses). Johnson seems to have been the first to report it (from Bukit Timah) but she didn't cite a specimen and none has been found. She reported it had club-shaped paraphyses in deep grooves which is certainly a character of parvulum and not of callifolium, however, all Antrophyum specimens that I have seen from Singapore are callifolium (with filiform paraphyses in shallow grooves). Treat as an Excluded Species on the basis that (a) no specimens and (b) lack of suitable habitats in Singapore for this limestone species. Also worth noting that Ridley (1926 - Ferns of the Malay Peninsula) {and probably Holttum 1955?} did not list Singapore for this species."		2135	Chong et al. (2009)	2135 - Chong et al. (2009)				Not in mockup {but should be in Excluded section of mockup}		Excluded	Yes	In Excluded section of Checklist ms	This name in db is absent from Checklist ms								Extinct	Nationally Extinct	no	epiphyte		None					urn:lsid:ipni.org:names:17023450-1		none	Excluded						10	10

4931					no		no	no	DJM			Asplenium cf. oxyphyllum J.Sm. ex Kunze	824		"LCVP says ""Asplenium oxyphyllum J.Sm."" is a synonym of Asplenium macrophyllum Sw."	POWO		1		IMT	IPNI gives incomplete authors and fails to note that J.Sm. is nom. nud.		https://www.ipni.org/n/17048730-1	POWO says Asplenium oxyphyllum J.Sm. ex Kunze is a synonym of Asplenium simile Blume	"Salgado & Fraser-Jenkins, Fern Gaz. 19(6): 227 (2013) [and possibly Salgado, Edinb. J. Bot. 74: 3 (2016)] argue that the name Asplenium polyodon is only applicable in Australisia and Pacific. Asian material is something else. FoPM (2020) treats polyodon as a misapplied name for Asplenium oxyphyllum, a species which (in PM) is mainly found on limestone rocks and rarely in soil on limestone making its presence in Singapore extremely unlikely. Its presence in Singapore is based on a single, old, incomplete specimen from Bukit Timah {check this; and check not a Cantley specimen}. The name Asplenium polyodon G.Forst. has never been used in the Singapore literature (Henk is the first to do so in his FoS ms -- is he still recognising this name or has he revised his ms, perhaps in favour of oxyphyllum?) but the single specimen on which this record is based was det. by Ridley (1926) as A. dimidiatium Sw., clearly misapplied because that is an American species that Beddome said is related to falcatum. The specimen seems to have originally been det. as A. falcatum. // // DJM: Henk has admitted it should be A. oxyphyllum"	yes	Beentje	Asplenium cf. oxyphyllum	Monilophyta	Polypodiopsida	Polypodiales	Aspleniaceae	Uncertain			45843	assessed here	45843 - assessed here				Not in mockup	n/a	Data Deficient	Yes	Data Deficient	372	Native; DD (assessed here). 4971	x				no	Excluded	no	no				Beilschmiedia roxburghiana Nees	1058	ok	Name and authors accepted by LCVP	IPNI (= POWO)	x	1			n/a		https://www.ipni.org/n/462937-1					Beilschmiedia roxburghiana	Spermatophyta	Magnoliopsida	Laurales	Lauraceae	no	"Currently accepted name is Beilschmiedia roxburghiana Nees. An Excluded species because despite the discovery of Beilschmiedia tonkinensis (Lecomte) Ridl. being reported in Nature Watch in 2005 (a sterile plant on Pulau Salu that the authors acknowledged needed more work to confirm) and being listed as native and CE in the RDB (2008) and Chong et al. (2009), Rogier De Kok says he has seen no specimens from Singapore. Rogier says that Beilschmiedia roxburghiana prefers to grow in dry evergreen, mixed deciduous and dry dipterocarp forests, often along rivers, sometimes over limestone, at 50975 m altitude. This makes its occurrence in Singapore unlikely but Rogier did point out that the current southern limit of the species is Johore so it isn''t totally impossible that it might be found in Singapore (Singapore would then become the southern limit of the species distribution). But without any fertile specimen as evidence this species must be excluded from the Flora of Singapore."		3869	Chong et al. (2009)	3869 - Chong et al. "Native; EN (Beentje et al., in prep.)."	no	Endangered	Yes	Endangered	2869	Native; EN (assessed here).							Endangered	Endangered	no	shrub		Pandanus monotheca Martelli; Pandanus ornatus Kurz	"Sometimes cited as Pandanus ornatus (Gaudich.) Kurz, but the reputed basionym, Fisquetia ornata Gaudich (1843) was nom. inval. Kurz (1869) accepted the name (based on the inval. name Fisquetia ornata Gaudich.) and provided a diagnosis by comparing the species with his P. helicopus Kurz and therefore validly published the name. Therefore, Kurz is the sole author of the name. Turner (1993) was incorrect to say that the name Pandanus ornatus is illegitimate. Pandanus ornatus Kurz serves as the basionym of the currently accepted name Benstonea ornata (Kurz) Callm. & Buerki."				urn:lsid:ipni.org:names:77124056-1	Pandanus ornatus Kurz; Pandanus monotheca Martelli	Pandanus monotheca Martelli; Pandanus ornatus Kurz	Endangered						4	21

597					yes	Excluded (Cultivated Only)	no	no				Connarus planchonianus G.Schellenb.	2186	ok	Name and authors accepted by LCVP	IPNI (= POWO)	x	1			n/a		https://www.ipni.org/n/264471-1		"SL: I don't understand where this status and rationale have come from: ""Status uncertain but likely to only ever have been in cultivation in Singapore"". I can find no evidence in the literature that anyone ever thought this was cultivated. Ridley never suggested it (incorrectly identified by him as as C. grandis) was cultivated or had uses (though it has a lot of common names -- see Fl. Malesiana -- which may suggest it had uses). Instead, Ridley said it was common in open ground. A paratype, Wallich 8538B (p.p.) from Singapore is at K. There are 7 specimens in SING from Changi (Ridley, Goodenough), Bukit Timah (Corner) and Pulau Ubin (Ridley) plus 2 Cantley specimens without details in Brahms. Last collected by Corner in 1938. Perhaps status should be returned to native and extinct? 4974	x				no	Excluded	yes	no				Dendrobium fugax Rchb.f.	2695	ok	Name and authors accepted by LCVP	IPNI (= POWO)	x	1			n/a		https://www.ipni.org/n/635203-1	POWO says Flickingeria fugax (Rchb.f.) Seidenf. is a synonym of Dendrobium fugax Rchb.f.				Dendrobium fugax	Spermatophyta	Magnoliopsida	Asparagales	Orchidaceae	no	"An Excluded species for the following reason: Ridley 1896 [J. Linn. Soc., Bot. 32: 240. (1896)] described Dendrobium roseopunctatum Ridl. from a plant collected somewhere in the ""Malay Peninsula"" (a geographical term that would have included Singapore) and cultivated at SBG. The type specimen, prepared from this cultivated plant is still at SBG [SING0049796]. Ridley 1924 [Ridl., Fl. Malay Penins. 4 (1924) 31] moved this species to Desmotrichum and repeated that it was from the ""Malay Peninsula"" but the exact locality was not known. As there is no other evidence that this taxon occurs naturally in Singapore (or even in Peninsular Malaysia -- it was not mentioned in any edition of Holttums Orchids of Malaya (1953-1971) or in Seidenfaden & Wood's Orchids of Peninsuular Malaysia and Singapore (1992)), it is best excluded from the Flora and Checklist. Seidenfaden reduced (with a ?) Dendrobium roseopunctatum to Flickingeria fugax in 1980 while admitting that he had not seen the type of D. roseopunctatum (saying it was not found in SING at the time), and also stating, as Ridley had done, that the type was of unknown origin flowering at SBG in 1893. This probably explains how the name Flickingeria fugax (Rchb.f.) Seidenf. got into Malaysian and Singaporean checklists although it certainly should never have been treated as native in Singapore by the Singapore RDB (2008), Chong et al. (2009) and Yam's Native Orchids of Singapore (2013) and there is now doubt that this little known taxon is even native to Peninsular Malaysia. Ong Poh Teck (FRIM) now considers that Seidenfaden was wrong to synonymise Dendrobium roseopunctatum under Flickingeria fugax and so it seems that that name has been misapplied in this region."		15281	Yam (2013)	15281 - Yam (2013)				Not in mockup {but should be in Excluded section of mockup}		Excluded	Yes	In Excluded section of Checklist ms only as synonym Flickingeria fugax (Rchb.f.) Seidenf. The current name Dendrobium fugax Rchb.f. has not been used in SL.	This name in db is absent from Checklist ms													Flickingeria fugax (Rchb.f.) Dichanthium mucronulatum	Spermatophyta	Magnoliopsida	Poales	Poaceae	no	"Dichanthium mucronulatum Jansen, otherwise known from limestone hills in southern Thailand and the Malay Peninsula (Langkawi, Pahang, Selangor), was once found in the Singapore Botanic Gardens as a casual (Ridley s.n., 1897, SING [SING0041424]). It has not been recorded from the Botanic Gardens or from anywhere else in Singapore in more than 120 years. While one could treat Dichanthium mucronulatum as 'formerly Casual' it was treated in the Flora of Singapore (2019) as 'Excluded'." She did not say the accepted range of this species or where she thought the SBG plant might have come from. // Carmen (Aug 2021) said: This is one of the most unfortunate choices of epithet in the history of botany! According to the FPM account (work in progress), this species is widespread in Pen Mal except for Perlis and the NE states. According to Ng (TFSS 2002: 91) it's also found in Sabah and Sarawak. I haven't verified these records yet and the Pen Mal part might be inaccurate. D. singaporensis was described from two specimens from one or two trees in cultivation at SBG whose original wild collection is unknown. When Bakhuizen van den Brink described it, and then again in the 1937 monograph, the two SING specimens were the only material he had seen for the species. Ng (TFM 1978) mentioned SG in the distribution, but it's probably just because of these two specimens, as I have not seen anything from SG vaguely resembling D. singaporensis, other than the tree grown in one of the lawns near the herbarium."		0						Not in mockup {but should be in Excluded section of mockup}		Excluded	Yes	In Excluded section of Checklist ms	This name in db is absent from Checklist ms													None					urn:lsid:ipni.org:names:323022-1		none	Excluded						3	3

"In the synonyms it lists for Gongronema wallichii (Wight) Decne, POWO incorrectly lists ""Vincetoxicum ventricosum Kuntze"" and ""Tylophora wallichii (Wight) Hook.f."" in the mistaken belief Tylophora wallichii (which is a genuine synonym of Vincetoxicum ventricosum Kuntze), is homotypic with Gongronema wallichii. Michele says it is not. The correct author for Tylophora wallichii is Tylophora wallichii Hook.f., not Tylophora wallichii (Wight) Hook.f. as is shown in POWO."		yes		Gongreos wallichii	Spermatophyta	Magnoliopsida	Gentianales	Apocynaceae	yes			45548	assessed here	45548 - assessed here			37452 - Yeoh & Rodda (2020)	"Native; NEpresumed Extinct but later rediscovered and pending re-evaluation (Yeoh & Rodda, 2020)."	yes	Critically Endangered	Yes	Critically Endangered	845	Native; CR (assessed here). 5044	x				no	Excluded	yes	no				Grypothrix salicifolia (Wall. ex Hook.) S.E.Fawc. & A.R.Sm.	4381		LCVP says accepted name is Cyclosorus salicifolius (Wall. ex Hook.) Copel.									POWO says Pronephrium salicifolium (Wall. ex Hook.) Holttum is a synonym of Thelypteris salicifolia (Wall. ex Hook.) C.F.Reed				Grypothrix salicifolia	Monilophyta	Polypodiopsida	Polypodiales	Thelypteridaceae	no	"Ridley (1908: 50; & Ridley 1926: 57) reported Meniscium salicifolium Wall. ex Hook. (now Pronephrium salicifolium (Wall. ex Hook.) Holttum) for Singapore based on a Bishop Hose collection from Selitar. This specimen has not been traced (not at SING or K) so it is unclear to what Ridley was referring. There are 3 Lobb specimens from ""Singapore"" at K (two s.n., the third no. 314). They are correctly identified but as with many Lobb specimens there is doubt as to whether they were really collected in Singapore. But Beddome's Ferns of British India (p. and t. 207) includes an illustration of Meniscium salicifolium declared as having being drawn from a Singapore specimen, but does not state any collection details so don't know if it was based on a Lobb specimen." Known from two recent collections		"Collected in 1992 (at SINU, though originally misidentified as Maytenus emarginata (Willd.) Ding Hou) and 2015 (according to Reuben and Ivan's FoS manuscript) so should never have been assessed as Extinct in 2008/2009 and was not a new record when reported correctly for the first time in Singapore as Gymnosporia littoralis, in 2003."				Extinct	Nationally Extinct	no	shrub		Maytenus emarginata auct. non (Willd.) Ding Hou	"Maytenus emarginata is considered to be a misidentification of the Singapore species. Jordaan & van Wyk (Telopea, 2003) say that specimens from Malay Peninsula (Johore) and Java determined by Ding Hou as Maytenus emarginata in 1962 are Gymnosporia littoralis and specimens named Maytenus emarginata by Ding Hou in 1962, occurring elsewhere in Malesia (Philippines, Celebes, Moluccas and New Guinea) and northern Queensland are Gymnosporia inermis. Genuine Maytenus emarginata (now Gymnosporia emarginata (Willd.) Thwaites) is only in India and Sri Lanka. Jordaan & van Wyk do not mention Singapore but the implication is that ""G. (Maytenus) emarginata"" from Singapore should be G. littoralis."				urn:lsid:ipni.org:names:70028176-1	Maytenus emarginata auct. non (Willd.) Ding Hou	Maytenus emarginata auct. non (Willd.) Soc. 59 (1911) 132, noted that it could not have come from Singapore despite the label information. Sw.	4829			IPNI	x	1		RG	POWO links to wrong IPNI ID and POWO has wrong author abbreviation.		https://www.ipni.org/n/98072-3					Hymenophyllum demissum	Monilophyta	Polypodiopsida	Hymenophyllales	Hymenophyllaceae	no	"Recorded for Singapore by Ridley (Malayan Branch Royal Asiatic Soc. 4, No. 1(96): 12 (1926)) but the sole collection cited by him, Ridley 1687 from Kranji, cannot be found. He earlier (Ridley, J. Straits Branch Roy. Asiat. Soc. 50: 11 (1908)) cited the same collection under the name Hymenophyllum productum. Hymenophyllum demissum is endemic to New Zealand. Hymenophyllum productum is widespread in Malesia (including Peninsular Malaysia, where a few old collections were originally misidentified as H. demissum) but it is usually found at elevations higher than are possible in Singapore. In what might be a repeated error rather than indicative of a mixed collection, Ridley (1908: 11; 1926: 14) also cites Ridley 1687 under Hymenophyllum denticulatum, a species that is known from Singapore. Ridley's Flora of Singapore (1900) makes no mention of Hymenophyllum demissum or H. productum but does mention H. denticulatum in the mangroves at Kranji."		0								Excluded	Yes	In Excluded section of Checklist ms	This name in db is absent from Checklist ms													None					urn:lsid:ipni.org:names:98072-3			Excluded						1	1

DJM			Lasianthus coronatus King & Gamble	5258			IPNI (= POWO)	x	1			n/a		https://www.ipni.org/n/754935-1		"This variety cannot be listed properly as a .2 number under a .0 species entry as this is not the current name (which is Lasianthus coronatus) and, moreover, the species name Lasianthus wallichii Wight is nom. illeg and now Lasianthus attenuatus which is already in the main table under its own number. This is another undesirable consequence of databasing Excluded species by their ""as published"" names, rather than by their currently accepted ones. This practice is messing-up the structure of (and logic behind) the main table." Wight & Arn.	5360	ok	Name and authors accepted by LCVP	IPNI (= POWO)	x	1			n/a		https://www.ipni.org/n/20009712-1					Leptadenia reticulata	Spermatophyta	Magnoliopsida	Gentianales	Apocynaceae	no	"Leptadenia reticulata (Retz.) Wight & Arn. was recorded for Singapore by King & Gamble in J. Asiat. Soc. Bengal, Pt. 2, Nat. Hist. 74(2) (1908) 596 based on Lobb 333. Ridley, Fl. Malay Penins. 2 (1923) 410 noted that this is a mistake and the specimen is erroneously localised. Infact, Ridley 1900: 114 was the first person to report a Lobb specimen from Singapore identified as Leptadenia reticulata. He didn't give the collection number 333 but did indicate that he thought it ""wrongly localised"", a view he evidently maintained in 1923." Leptochilus macrophyllus var. pedunculatus	Monilophyta	Polypodiopsida	Polypodiales	Polypodiaceae	no	"Ridley (1900: 194) and Ridley (1908: 49) reported Selliguea membranacea Blume (now Leptochilus macrophyllus (Blume) Noot. var. pedunculatus (Hook. & Grev.) Noot.) for Singapore based on a specimen in Moore's herbarium (apparently first reported by Beddome). This specimen has not yet been traced so it is unclear to what this name refers. Ridley (1926: 89), also citing Selliguea membranacea in Moore's herbarium, says the Singapore ""locality is doubtful"". Leptochilus macrophyllus var. pedunculatus has not otherwise been reported for Singapore (although one specimen of Tectaria singaporiana at SING was originally wrongly determined as Colysis penduculata and labelled ""first record for Singapore"")."		0								Excluded	Yes	In Excluded section of Checklist ms only as synonym Selliguea membranacea (Blume) Blume. Spermatophyta	Magnoliopsida	Laurales	Lauraceae	no	"Ridley (1900: 132) listed ""Litsea nitida Blume"" from Bukit Mandai but no specimen bearing this name has been found. Moreover, Blume never published this name and the real Litsea nitida (Roxb. ex Nees) Hook.f. occurs from the E. Himalaya to Myanmar. It is not known in Thailand or anywhere further south. It is likely that Ridley misapplied the name ""Litsea nitida Blume"" to another species of Litsea." 257					yes		no	no				Mangifera subsessilifolia Kosterm.	5869	ok	Name and authors accepted by LCVP	IPNI (= POWO)	x	1			n/a		https://www.ipni.org/n/978633-1			yes		Mangifera subsessilifolia	Spermatophyta	Magnoliopsida	Sapindales	Anacardiaceae	yes			46194	assessed here	46194 - assessed here		39093 - Ganesan (in prep.)	22164 - Chong et al. (2009)	"Native; VU (Chong et al., 2009)."	yes	Critically Endangered	Yes	Critically Endangered	708	Native; CR (assessed here).			I don't understand why this was classed as Vulnerable when it has clearly been CR for a long time. The one mature tree known fell down 15 Nov 2018 but Ali says there are a few juveniles nearby. Ganesan (July 2018) says: This species was previously but wrongly identified as as M. macrocarpa. M. macrocarpa is not in Singapore. At least some trees previously det. as M. macrocarpa are Mangifera quadrifida Jack. but these misidentified ones were never published as quadrifida. The earlier Index Kewensis combination is not validly published because elsewhere Jackson does not accept the combination. "Possibly a dubious record. Reported second-hand (from Bishop Hose) in Ridley 1926 (as Lastrea dayi) and much later by Johnson (1977, as Thelypteris singalanensis, which is believed by some to be misapplied to Metathelypteris dayi) but no specimen at SING. A Matthew specimen from Bukit Timah at K originally det. ""N. dayi"" has been redet. by Holttum as A. immersum (juvenile). Phalaenopsis violacea	Spermatophyta	Magnoliopsida	Asparagales	Orchidaceae	no	"Reported to be a native of Singapore (Warner ????; Fl. Brit. India, 1890) and to have been sent to European from Singapore (Reichenbach, Gard. Chron., n.s., 10: 234 (1878); Anonymous, Flor. Mag. 1879, t. 342; Anonymous, Gard. Chron., n.s., 16: 144 (1881), but no specimens have been found. While live plants were distributed from Singapore (at least by Murton, from SBG) it is unlikely to have been native here. Rolf (Gard. Chron. 1886, 2, p. 277:) considered it to be a native of Sumatra, and Holttum (1953: 663) says ''in Malaya only found in Perak and Selangor'."		0								Excluded	Yes	"In Excluded section of Checklist ms only as synonym Phalaenopsis violacea Teijsm. & Binn., nom. illeg. hom. 2661					no	Excluded (Cultivated Only)	yes	no	DJM			Platycerium grande (A.Cunn. ex Hook.) J.Sm.	7385		Name and/or authors not accepted by LCVP	POWO		1		IMT	IPNI has incomplete basionym authors.		https://www.ipni.org/n/17177490-1	Authors of name as given in Flora Malesiana are wrong.	"I think there is a big nomenclatural issue with P. grande versus P. superbum that needs to be resolved, possibly requiring a conservation proposal. I think the name P. grande (nowadays used for a species endemic to the Philippines) is based on an Australian collection. It is not the same taxon recognised as P. grande in the Philippines."		Hovenkamp	Platycerium grande	Monilophyta	Polypodiopsida	Polypodiales	Polypodiaceae	no	"Beddome (Ferns Brit. India, 2: 326 (????) stated the range of Platycerium grande (A.Cunn.) J.Sm. to include Singapore, Philippines and N. Australia but Ridley (1908: 55) pointed out that no-one else had seen it in Singapore. Additionally, Fée (Mém. Foug., 2. Hist. Acrostich. 103 (1845)) reported that Gaudichaud had collected Neuroplatyceros grandis (a synonym of Platyceroim grande) in Singapore but Gaudichaud's Singapore specimens are actually P. coronarium. Nowadays, Platycerium grande is considered endemic to the Philippines (Hennipman & Roos, Fl. Males, ser. 2, 3: 139 (1998) but is widely cultivated elsewhere, including in Singapore. Underwood (Bull. Torrey Bot. Club, 32: 594 (1905)) also included Singapore in the native range of P. grande."		27255	Chong et al. (2009)	27255 - Chong et al. (2009)				Not in mockup (because Cultivated Only)	$	Excluded (Cultivated Only)	Yes	In Excluded section of Checklist ms as this and as synonym Alcicornium grande (A.Cunn. ex Hook.) Underw. Karthik. & Moorthy	7433	ok	Name and authors accepted by LCVP	IPNI (= POWO)	x	1			n/a		https://www.ipni.org/n/185630-1	POWO used to say Blumea membranacea DC. is a synonym of Pluchea paniculata (Willd.) Karthik. & Moorthy but now it only says Blumea membranacea DC. is a synonym without saying of what.	POWO used to say Blumea membranacea DC. is a synonym of Pluchea paniculata (Willd.) Karthik. & Moorthy but now it only says Blumea membranacea DC. is a synonym without saying of what. So Pluchea paniculata (Willd.) Karthik. & Moorthy might not be the currently accepted name but for practical purposes must treat as such for now. How did it get into the RDB and Chong et al (2009) as a native and vulnerable species? 13 specimens at SING. Brani on ""slope above landing jetty below officers mess"". Sinclair records it as native here but I thinks it's more likely to have been planted and then naturalised. Similarily on P. Ubin from where many of the recent collections are from and where it is now abundant along roadsides. // Turner at al. GBS (1994) reported it for the first time [presumably Sinclair's 1950 collection not published?] and concluded it was not native. Who reclassified it as native for the RDB?" I have not yet encountered it in the wild.//DJM: I agree, I have changed this to naturalised"	yes		Pteris tripartita	Monilophyta	Polypodiopsida	Polypodiales	Pteridaceae	no			45871	assessed here	45871 - assessed here			28505 - Chong et al. (2009)	"Native; EN (Chong et al., 2009)."	no	Cryptogenic	Yes	Cryptogenic	545	Cryptogenic (assessed here).	"Changed from Naturalised to Cryptogenic because its origin, and apparent recent spead, requires further thought. There is no evidence this species was present until reported by Holttum who only reported it in SBG. Not true; Stuart to revise this. Holttum's wording may actually imply was present elsewhere in Singapore. Moreover, one Ridley specimen collected from Serangoon Road in 1900 appears to be Pteris tripartita. That said, Ridley (1908) did not list Singapore as a locality for P. tripartita (because at the time his Serangoon Road specimen was incorrectly identified as P. wallichiana). Ridley (1926) cited only 2 specimens of tripartita from Singapore, Wallich ""410"" that should be 110 and there is doubt it is from Singapore rather than Penang (and doubt that it is tripartita) and I cannot find and a Lobb specimen; he continue to incorrectly cite his Serangoon Road specimen as P. wallichianum). Serangoon Road was the locality of other problematic Ridley Pteris records: He cited only one Singapore specimen for each of P. quadriaurita, P. biaurita and P. wallichiana and all are from Serangoon Road (now confirmed that his ""biaurita"" and ""wallichiana"" from Serangoon Road were based on the same specimen which is in fact Pteris tripartita). What was there at that time? How wild was it? Are all these plants likely to have been in cultivation, or escaped from cultivation, on Serangoon Road." 4975					no		yes	no				Selaginella argentea (Wall. ex Hook. & Grev.) Spring	8378	ok	Name and authors accepted by LCVP	IPNI (= POWO)	x	1			n/a		https://www.ipni.org/n/60467464-2		"Khoon Meng's account of Selaginellaceae for the FoPM indicates that the most southerly recorded distribution of Selaginella argentea (in Peninsular Malaysia) is the northern boundary of Pahang. In 2019 Khoon Meng said he doubts it occurs in Singapore (pers. comm. Apr 2019), but in Jan. 2022 he confirmed that 2 specimens from Thomson Road area are S. argentea. He has not yet said if he considers these native or naturalised. According to Neo et al., until these Thomson Road specimens were found there had only ever been one collection (Cantley). It is supposed to be at SING. It seems that all citations of the name before 2014 were based on this single Cantley specimen (is it really from Singapore?). It is therefore a mystery why the RDB (2008) and Chong et al. (2009) claimed this was CR rather than Extinct." (2009)				Not in mockup (because Cultivated Only)	n/a	Cultivated Only	Yes		Absent from Checklist ms because Cultivated Only								Cultivated Only		yes	tree		Spondias cytherea Sonn.	"TL2 points out that Parkinson's descriptions were not intended to be new species description and that Merrill had proposed that most of Parkinson's names in ""A Journal of a Voyage to the South Seas, in His Majesty's Ship, the Endeavour..."" (1773) should be rejected. If that is done (as IPNI has already done for some of Parkinsons names) then the correct author would need to be a later author, most probably Spondias dulcis G.Forst., Fl. Ins. Austr. 34 (1786). But POWO accepts Parkinson as the author of this name. As long as Parkinson is the accepted author then Spondias dulcis Parkinson (1773) has priority over Spondias dulcis G.Forst. (1786) and Spondias cytherea Sonn., Voy. Indes Orient., ed. 2, 3: 242 (1782). But if Parkinson's name is not accepted then Spondias cytherea Sonn. would be the correct name. Mitchell & Daly (A revision of Spondias L. (Anacardiaceae) in the Neotropics -- PhytoKeys 55: 192 (2015) doi: 10.3897/phytokeys.55.8489), explain on p25 the long debate over the validity of Parkinson's name but they also accept it."				urn:lsid:ipni.org:names:71455-1	Spondias cytherea Sonn. "7 specimens (9 sheets) listed in SING Brahms db but can only find 2 very old wild collected specimens on the shelves (one dated 1880 (very faint writing, no locaity); the other dated 1906, from Bukit Panjang). "Only 5 old specimens at SING and one collected in 1960 at SINU; Last collected by Wee in 1960 (SINU) and most recent before that was Ridley in 1893 (SING). Holttum (in Ferns of Malaya, 1954, 1968) said it still occurs at Bukit Timah. A sterile frond was collected in Fern Valley in March 2021 which represents a rediscovery of this species. It is hard to explain why this species was classed as Endangered in the RDB and Chong et al. (2009), when the specimen evidence clearly warranted an assessment of Extinct."		Yi Shuen and I collected a sterile plant in Fern Valley in March 2021. Holttum's wording implies that in Singapore only known from Bukit Timah and all the specimens with locality info. Tectaria semibipinnata	Monilophyta	Polypodiopsida	Polypodiales	Tectariaceae	no	"Ridley (1900) reported Aspidium semibipinnatum Wall. ex Hook. [now Tectaria semibipinnata (Wall. ex Hook.) Copel.] from Bukit Timah, Bajau and Bukit Mandai but when he listed this species in 1908 (Ferns of Malaya) and in 1926 he did not include any Singapore specimens. Tectaria semibipinnata is a species of muddy river banks in the tidal zone so is unlikely to have been present at Bukit Timah or Bukit Mandai. It is not known what Ridley misapplied this name to in Singapore."		0								Excluded	Yes	In Excluded section of Checklist ms only as synonym Aspidium semibipinnatum Wall. ex Hook. "Only 4 specimens at SING; first collected 2004, last 2016 (CR might be appropriate -- Ask Cherish who has seen plants recently). Ridley 1900 reported it (as Aspidium vastum) from Bukit Timah and P. Ubin but there is some doubt as to whether Ridley applied the name correctly as the only specimen found from Bukit Timah labelled ""Nephrodium vastum"" is actually Tectaria semipinnata and the only two localities for T. semipinnata in Singapore are Bukit Timah and P. Ubin. Given Ridley's (1900) claims it is open to debate whether T. vasta should have been published as a rediscovery in 2004 or as a new record. Check with Cherish; there may now be no wild plants known following recent land clearance."				Endangered	Endangered	no	herb		Aspidium vastum Blume; Sagenia alata (Wall. ex Hook. & Grev.) Changed from CR to Extinct because no specimens of mature plants collected since 1960's and there is doubt over the ID of some recent very juvenile bathophylls.		"Extinct? only 9 specimens at SING, mostly bathophylls and mostly from Bukit Timah, last collected 1931 although Wee posted photos on Facebook in 2018 of aculeatum at Bukit Timah in the 1960's. SL & YS found 4 very young plants (bearing only small bathophylls) in Fern Valley in March 2021 that exactly match a specimen labelled by Holltum as aculeatum. BUT I am starting to suspect that Holttum might have confused the earliest stages of aculeatum and ludens so further work is required to be 100% sure aculeatum has been rediscovered." 5282	x				no		no	no	x			Trachyspermum roxburghianum (DC.) Craib	9303			$		2		IMT	See comments under issues		$		"DJM to check authors. Most of the text here is based on confusing IPNI entries visible before Dec 2021. IPNI entries for this name and most of the synonymy changed in Dec 2021, such that IPNI & POWO now say Trachyspermum roxburghianum H.Wolff. So authorship has changed and needs to be checked. Apium involucratum Roxb. (1810) might still be the earliest name for this taxon, if the extremely brief protologue is acceptable. [[Basionym of Trachyspermum roxburghianum (DC.) Craib may be nom. illeg. superf. SL doesn't think the combo is properly made by Benth & Hook. f. [as claimed by IPNI]// see Benth & Hook.f (1867) https://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/page/656984#page/185/mode/1up versus Kurz (1877) https://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/110105#page/124/mode/1up. But there is also Carum roxburghianum Waring, Pharmacopoeia India 108 (1868), nom. illeg. superfl [according to IPNI]. (probably also based on Ptychotis roxburghiana DC. (1830) even though IPNI does not show the basionym]. I think the reputed basionym Ptychotis roxburghiana DC. is nom. illleg. superfl. although none of the databases say this -- see https://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/page/152255#page/114/mode/1up. Consequently, of all the synonyms listed by POWO, I think the basionym that has priority is Apium involucratum Roxb. (1810), meaning the correct name of this taxon should be Trachyspermum involucratum, not T. roxburghianum as POW0 claims. /// Check authors: (DC.) Benth. & Hook.f. ex Kurz {(DC.?) Benth. & Hook.f. (ex Kurz?)}]]"			Trachyspermum roxburghianum	Spermatophyta	Magnoliopsida	Apiales	Apiaceae	no			43536	Clarke in Hooker (1879)	43536 - Clarke in Hooker (1879)						Cultivated Only	Yes		Absent from Checklist ms because Cultivated Only													Carum roxburghianum (DC.) Zingiber chryseum Ridl.	"Zingiber puberulum var. chryseum was described in 1908 by Ridley (as Z. chryseum) from the woods in the Stagmount area (Singapore). The forest in this area was cleared shortly thereafter and
no further material of this taxon has ever been collected. It is presumed, therefore, to have gone extinct in Singapore (Jana, pers comm. 19 April 2018). See Leong-[S]korni[c]ková et al., Gard. Bull.
